## Target and Features Relationship

* In ML, we want to be "lazy". We do not want to specify $f$ manually.

* We want to learn it **automatically from labeled data**.

* Later we will see that we do have to specify something, like $f$'s functional form and other
  stuff.

* Mathematically, we face a problem of function approximation: search for an
  $f$, such that, for all points in the training data, and also all newly
  observed points

\begin{center}
  \begin{tikzpicture}[->,>=stealth',shorten >=1pt,auto,node distance=1cm,
      thick,main node/.style={circle,fill=blue!20,draw,font=\sffamily\Large\bfseries}]
    \node[punkt] (natur) {$y \approx f(x)$};
    \node[left=of natur] (x) {x};
    \node[right=of natur] (y) {y};
    \path[every node/.style={font=\sffamily\small}]
    (natur) edge node {} (y)
    (x) edge node  {} (natur)
    ;
  \end{tikzpicture}
\end{center}

* We call this **supervised learning**.

## What is a Model?

A model takes the features of new observations and produces a prediction $\hat{y}$ of our target variable $y$:

```{r, fig.align="center", out.width="0.7\\textwidth", echo=FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics(ap("figure/the_model_web.png"))
```

<!-- **But:** How do we obtain a model? -->

## What is an Inducer?

The **inducer** (learner, algorithm) takes our labeled data set (**training set**) and
produces a model (which again is a function):

\vspace{-0.5cm}

```{r, fig.align="center", out.width="0.7\\textwidth", echo=FALSE}
knitr::include_graphics(ap("figure/the_inducer_web.png"))
```
